text:
Canal Street, west from the southern end of Thompson Street, prior to the digging of the Independent (municipal) Subway and the south-bound extension of Sixth Avenue. The first step taken will be the demolition of all the buildings on the north side of Canal Street from Thompson to Sullivan Streets.

1926.

Sixth Avenue, south across Canal Street, showing this new extension and its subway under construction. Dominating the background is the New York Telephone Company building. This is to be included in a new structure without interruption to service. View 3 shows this constructional stage. The cupola atop the Municipal Building is to the right.

September 9, 1927
October 19, 1928
April 16, 1931

P. L. Sperr

title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue Extension - North Canal Street.

text:
(1) Canal Street, north side, from Thompson Street to West Broadway (formerly South Fifth Avenue), seen from the eastern end of Laight Street. September 24, 1927. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, a year later, seen from York Street at West Broadway, across the site of the buildings between York and Canal Streets. Canal Street is being supported on stilts which the construction of the subway goes on underneath; the view at the left is practically north along the future east side of Sixth Avenue. Krist's Bakery, the light house with the dormer window, is No. 387 Canal Street. In the background of both these views may be seen the steeple of St. Alphonsus' Roman Catholic Church. October 10, 1928. P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same as No. 2, as seen from Sixth Ave. Extension at West Broadway. Elevated shown is the Sixth Ave. line. March 19, 1932. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, a year later, seen from York Street at West Broadway, across the site of the buildings between York and Canal Streets. Canal Street is being supported on stilts which the construction of the subway goes on underneath; the view at the left is practically north along the future east side of Sixth Avenue. Krist's Bakery, the light house with the dormer window, is No. 387 Canal Street. In the background of both these views may be seen the steeple of St. Alphonsus' Roman Catholic Church. (3) The same as No. 2, as seen from Sixth Ave. Extension at West Broadway. Elevated shown is the Sixth Ave. line. March 19, 1932. P. L. Sperr.

(1) Canal Street, north side, west from Thompson Street and Sixth Avenue Extension. All the buildings from Thompson to Sullivan Streets have been demolished, and the west side of Sullivan Street, from Canal to Grand Streets, will form the west side of this part of Sixth Avenue. The eight-story Peter Frasse & Company building stands at the N.W. corner of Canal and Sullivan Streets. The ten-story Powell Chocolate factory, on the N.E. corner, has just been demolished. December 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same at a later date and showing a view northward on the new Sixth Ave. Extension. On the left appears a portion of Varick Street.

P. L. Sperr.

December 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same at a later date and showing a view northward on the new Sixth Ave. Extension. On the left appears a portion of Varick Street.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
4-10 Thompson Street, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of Canal Street. Nos. 8-10 is the St. Alphonsus R.C. Church, with the Parochial School (Nos. 4-6) adjoining. This view is as seen from the new Sixth Ave. Extension and during its construction period.
October 19, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, during demolition period.
September 9, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, slightly more extensive; at a later date, as seen from the S.W. corner of Laight at Varick St's.
June 3, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

Sixth Avenue, north across Canal Street, as photographed from atop the American Thread Company Building at West Broadway and Beach Street. Shown is this new diagonal extension to the Avenue and its subway line underground. The old "El" line is at the right, running on West Broadway along the front of St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church.

October 17, 1928
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr

October 17, 1928
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, north across Canal Street as photographed from atop the Carborundem Building on Laight at Canal Streets. Under construction is the new Avenue extension and its municipal subway underground. This new thoroughfare in its diagonal path crosses several others; that on the left being what was formerly Sullivan Street. Thompson Street is on the right. Upon the latter abuts the rear of St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church.

October 18, 1928
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, east side, north from above Canal Street, showing constructional details of this new diagonal extension and its subway underground. Grand Street is in the midground and the buildings there face on both sides of same. These extend east to Thompson Street. View 2 is photographed at Grand Street.

October 19, 1928
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, south across Canal Street, showing this new diagonal extension to the Avenue. Dominating the view is the New York Telephone Company Building. It occupies the plot bounded by Sixth Avenue, from Lispenard to Walker Streets, east to Church Street.
Note the old 6th Avenue "El" line running on West Broadway.
This was taken down in 1939.
View 1: March 20, 1932
View 2: May 19, 1933
P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, south across Canal Street, showing this new diagonal extension to the Avenue. Dominating the view is the New York Telephone Company Building. It occupies the plot bounded by Sixth Avenue, from Lispenard to Walker Streets, east to Church Street.
Note the old 6th Avenue "El" line running on West Broadway.
This was taken down in 1939.
View 1: March 20, 1932
View 2: May 19, 1933
P. L. Sperr

(1)

Sixth Ave., east side, north from but not including Canal to and including Grand Streets. Note frame houses (No's 29 and 31 Grand Street) between Sixth Ave. and Thompson Street.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(2)

The same, a further view. 1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - N. Canal Street - Grand Street

text:
Former home of the People's Bank, 395 Canal Street at the N.E. corner of Thompson Street, and the gap adjoining, where No. 391 stood. The timbers buttress the east wall of No. 395 and the west wall of 389 against each other.

March 19, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

2, 4-6, 8-10 Thompson Street, at, adjoining and north of Canal Street, showing the parochial school and back door of St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church.

May 19, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
391-387 Canal Street, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Thompson Street. Krist's Bakery is located at No. 387.
October 21, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date. In the rear of the houses appears part of St. Alphonsus (R.C.) Church, situated on West Broadway, between Canal and Grand Streets.
May 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
391-387 Canal Street, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Thompson Street. Krist's Bakery is located at No. 387.

May 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Canal Street (foreground), from Laight (left), to Vestry (right) Streets, as viewed southwestward from Thompson Street. To the left and across a cleared square where the former St. Johns Park depot of the New York City Railroad stood, appear loft structures on the west side of Hudson Street; prominent of which is the 14 story Green Industrial Building at the S.W. corner of Hubert Street. The Ballantine sign is on the easterly side of the storage warehouses extending thru Laight to Vestry Streets and form a new west side for this block (demolition for Holland Tunnel exit which is at the extreme right). The white structure at the latter point is the Green Terminal Building, at the N.E. corner of Hudson and Vestry Streets.

P.L. Sperr

March 11, 1938.
